name: Peace Lily
description: The Peace Lily is a graceful flowering plant known for its elegant white blooms and deep green foliage. Native to tropical regions of the Americas and southeastern Asia, it's beloved for its ability to thrive in low-light conditions while purifying indoor air.

care.water: When soil feels dry, about weekly

proTip: The leaves will droop slightly when it needs water - it's the plant's way of communicating with you!
mindfulnessPrompt: Like the Peace Lily's graceful drooping when thirsty, notice how your body signals its needs. What is it asking for today?

name: Snake Plant
description: The Snake Plant, also known as Mother-in-Law's Tongue, is a resilient succulent with striking upright leaves marked with green and yellow patterns. This hardy plant is perfect for beginners and busy lifestyles.
benefits: Converts CO2 to oxygen at night

care.water: Every 2-4 weeks, let soil dry completely

proTip: Overwatering is the most common mistake - when in doubt, wait another week!
mindfulnessPrompt: Observe the Snake Plant's steady, upright growth. Stand tall like its leaves and take three deep breaths, feeling your own strength and resilience.

name: Golden Pothos
description: The Golden Pothos is a flowing vine with heart-shaped leaves in vibrant green and golden yellow. Known for its trailing growth habit, it's perfect for hanging baskets or climbing up moss poles.

care.water: When top inch of soil is dry

proTip: Trim leggy vines to encourage fuller growth, and propagate the cuttings in water!
mindfulnessPrompt: Watch how the Pothos reaches and grows toward light. Reflect on what you're naturally drawn toward and how you can honor that growth.

name: Rubber Tree
description: The Rubber Tree is a stunning houseplant with glossy, dark green leaves that can grow quite large. Native to India and Southeast Asia, it makes an impressive statement piece in any room.

care.water: When top 2 inches of soil are dry

proTip: Wipe the leaves regularly with a damp cloth to keep them glossy and help the plant photosynthesize better.
mindfulnessPrompt: Notice the Rubber Tree's broad, reaching leaves. Spread your arms wide and breathe deeply, embracing your own capacity to take up space.

name: Monstera Deliciosa
description: The Monstera Deliciosa, also known as the Swiss Cheese Plant, is famous for its large, split leaves that develop unique holes and splits as the plant matures. It's a tropical climbing plant that brings jungle vibes indoors.

care.water: When top inch of soil is dry

proTip: Provide a moss pole or trellis for climbing - the leaves will grow larger and develop more splits!
mindfulnessPrompt: Like the Monstera's leaves that develop splits and holes over time, consider how life's openings and changes create new beauty in your own growth.

name: ZZ Plant
description: The ZZ Plant is a striking succulent with glossy, dark green leaves that grow in graceful, arching stems. Native to Eastern Africa, it's incredibly drought-tolerant and perfect for low-light spaces.

care.water: Every 2-3 weeks, let soil dry completely

proTip: The rhizomes store water, so yellow leaves usually mean overwatering - less is more!
mindfulnessPrompt: The ZZ Plant thrives with minimal care, storing what it needs. Reflect on the resources you already have within you and how you can nurture yourself simply.

name: Spider Plant
description: The Spider Plant is nature's gift that keeps on giving. This cheerful, arching plant produces adorable plantlets that dangle like spiders from a web, making it perfect for sharing with friends and expanding your plant family effortlessly.
benefits: Produces baby plants for easy propagation
proTip: Leave the babies (plantlets) attached to the mother plant until they develop roots, then cut and pot them up!
mindfulnessPrompt: Watch your Spider Plant nurture its babies while still connected. Reflect on the ways you can support others while maintaining your own growth and well-being.

name: Fiddle Leaf Fig
description: The Fiddle Leaf Fig is the supermodel of the plant worldâ€”stunning, dramatic, and a little high-maintenance. Its large, violin-shaped leaves create an instant focal point and bring a touch of elegance to any room willing to meet its specific needs.

care.water: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil are dry

proTip: Fiddle Leaf Figs hate change! Find the perfect spot and avoid moving them around to prevent leaf drop.
mindfulnessPrompt: Notice how your Fiddle Leaf Fig responds to consistency in care. Consider the areas of your life that also flourish with steady, mindful attention.
